Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2007 10:26AM Jenniferz wrote: First, many prayers and gentle hugs for your loss.    Catherineanne, it means you MAY have a problem.  And it doesn't necessarily mean cancer.  Your gp is just being extra careful (be thanksful for that) and sending you to a specialist doesn't spell doom.  Since I'm not a doctor, I don't know what it means, but you are very wise in getting in checked out. Someone much wiser than I am and better in calming nerves will be in here soon, so please hang on.  IF (and I do mean if) it is breast cancer, then you probably have caught it early.  I have learned through this journey that breast cancer does not equal doom.  (Although,  I must admit, I thought the same when I was first diagnosed. ) Please try and relax, and again, many prayers to you and your family through this most trying of times.

Posts.Content: Jenniferz wrote: On April 28, I will cross the threshhokd that we look forward too--5 years and cancer free. I was diagnosed in 2006 with Idc and dcis in ny left breast. Both tumors together didn't measure up to 1 cm., but I elected to have a mrm. At the time of my diagnosis, I did not receive chemotherapy, rads, or herceptin...two separate oncs. decided that the mx was enough. And I have to trust that they are right. Time has moved on-- and I am dancing with Ned. Life has moved forward, and so am I. I am now the primary caregiver to my mother. It is entirely to stressful at times, but I wouldn't miss this oportunity for all the tea in China! But, because of the fullness of life, I feel I must move on. Most of you don't know me, or don't remeber me--- and that's ok. I have gathered much information from a very amazing group of ladies, and I certainly will never forget any of you. It is my wis, prayer, and hope that we all be disease free, and that the elusive cure is just around that corner. So with that, I goodbye and thank you fir all the info and hand holding that you have done. God's blessing to you all. Jennifer Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 12, 2008 10:01AM Jenniferz wrote: To have or not have a mastectomy is truly a personal choice that only YOU can answer, not your doctors, not your loved ones....only you.  My suggestion would be to do your research, then make a list of the pros and cons of mastectomy.  And don't rush into it.  Breathe, and think.  If you have a lumpectomy and on the chance that the dcis comes back in the same breast, you can always have a mastectomy at that time. It may NEVER come back....remember that. Jennifer

Posts.Content: May 5, 2010 12:07AM - edited May 5, 2010 12:10AM by Jenniferz I am four years out, with no recon. I've regained a tiny portion of feeling at my mastectomy site, but not very much. It is mostly numb from from the center of my chest wrapping to the left side of my arm pit.. I do still get the phantom pains, but have mostly learned to ignore them. The cold does effect the site, and I think it's because there isn't really any fat there to protect these old bones! My surgeon said that if not much more feeling hasn't returned by now, then most likely, it won't. This is what pretains to ME, now others may heal differently.

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2009 01:02PM - edited Dec 21, 2009 01:04PM by Jenniferz I hope this is NOT true, as there is an awful lot going on in my family right now, and most of it is not good. However, stress does mess up your auto-immune system, causing one to weaken and get many other illnesses, so why not have it help the cancer move along, too.  I was diagnoses the year I retired.....so really, there was no stress that was out of the ordinary.  OR, could there have been, and I just didn't know?  My father was murdered within the 8-10 year timespan when cancer develops, and that was/is traumatic, so---------------------?(Now cold case) One day, we'll know the answer.  Not going to stress out over what did cause the cancer, nor will I stress out over what mistakes I did or do that will cause it to start up again.  I just take each day as it comes, and do the best I can! Seasons Blessings, everyone! Jennifer

Posts.Title: Cloth Cover w/Prothesis tos Jenniferz

Posts.Content: Jenniferz wrote: I had posted this in the IDC threads, and alicesuzy asked that I post this here as well.  My point in this is that everyone should have IN THEIR HANDS a copy of every report and every result that you can.  If I had had mine 18 months earlier, maybe I would be feeling a lot less shaky than I have been.  However, this too shall pass-- ----------------------------------- I'm in somewhat of a tizzy.  I went in for my 6th month checkup with my surgeon today.  Everything is fine as far as he can tell.  That's not what has me going.  Bear with me ---this could be somewhat long.  In speaking with my surgeon, I told him because I am now on another insurance, I had to find a new onc. because the one that I had now is no longer under the insurance umbrella.  He said that that was fine, that he knew the onc. I am going to switch to, then he said he wanted to review my case with me.  Ok, I thought---this is interesting. He then asked how long it's been since my surgery.  It's been 18 months yesterday (yea, me!!).  He said that since I was er/pr+, and her2+, then the mastectomy was the best choice for me, even though my tumor was so tiny. He left to make copies of my records, and my mind just exploded. After a rapid discussion w/dh (who goes with me faithfully every time I get examined---thank God), we spoke to the surgeon again.  ALL this time, I have been thinking I was er/pr-, but knew I was her2 positive.  I asked him again about the pathology report, and he showed it to me: er/pr+.  There it was in black in white.  I swear, the onc said er/pr-.  I know this because he said I was one for three---meaning I was her2 positvie only.  It states clearly in the letter he sent my surgeon, that I was not a candidate for chemo or radiation in that I had a mastec. and n0, m0.  BUT, he put me on Femara, even though he told me I was hormone neg., and he wanted to give me something to make me feel like I was getting the best I could get. Bottom line is that I feel cheated.  18 months out, and I feel like I DIDN'T get the best.  Good grief I was triple POSITVE (as opposed to neg.)  I think it states in the pathology report that the tumor was .3 cm at the largest point.  I don't have it with me right now...I can post that later if someone wants to see. I had IDC, high grade, with one DCIS high grade as well.  If I read the darn thing right. Wouldn't you think I would have qualified for SOMETHING????  Am I now doomed??? I was feeling sort of good about things, but know all old doubts have fired up again, and the "elephant has taken over the room". My surgeon says I will have to be forever vigilant on the left side.  I had already figured that out as I do bi-monthly se's now.  A bit of an overkill maybe, but hey---. And I feel like I have not been truthful here.  I have been telling people, "no-no er/pr-, but on Femara anyway."  I was thinking all this time it was just some sort of weird preventative this man had me doing.  Evidently not.  I can clearly remember this man telling both my dh and I that I didn't even have to take Femara....that all should be well for me in the future.  Because he misspoke himself, I was going to ask the new onc. if I could stop.  Don't think that's gonna happen.  I'll be taking this drug forever if need be!  Thin hair and all--- This year I really was enjoying the holiday season.  Now I sit here in absolute dread again. This creep....this man....I don't even know if he really read my records.  Just skimmed them.  Told me I didn't need Herceptin.  And now, the door closed. I don't know what I expect from you dear people.  There's nothing you can do.  I guess I just needed to get this off my chest. Thanks for listening. Jennifer Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Onc Misspoke--Maybe(?) Jenniferz Shirlann
